												Operation Flashpoint: Red River is kind of like a mixture of ArmA, MOH and Ghost Recon. You command your fireteam (like GR) except in a more complicated way similar to ArmA (stance, dispersion, noise dicipline etc.) There are ArmA features like bullet drop, the importance of stance when aiming, military jargon that is relevant to the task and some adherence to military tactics. The AI (unlike ArmA) are actually somewhat lifelike, and they behave much like the AI in say MOH BF3/4 and GR. Unfortunately, the environment isn't breakable (like BF3/4), however you can reduce buildings to rubble with high explosives but that is it. Suppressors aren't that useful because of the way the campaign is played (open ground and daylight) but fortunately they do not reduce damage like in some games. The weapons are rather innacurate, almost to the point that they are unusable. The M4A1 carbine is good for distances up to max 20m away (the ACOG magnifies too much). The M249E2 SAW is about the same. The MP5A4 is good for targets up to 10m away. The M14 is best with the Leupold Mk 4 because the ACOG sits too far forward on the weapon and the peripherals interfere. The M107 is useful for any range, but if targets are within 100m, then aim using the graduations above the middle of the crosshair. In conclusion, I would recommend it to anyone. It's fun by yourself (the AI are competent) and fun with friends or even strangers (the online community are quite pleasant).

												I've seen a lot of people compare this to Arma or Battlefield, and then say this game is rather dissapointing. The game is more like MoH or CoD, in the sense that it isn't openworld, and the missions are very linear. Where it differs from MoH or CoD however is in the gameplay. Unlike you're generic FPS military game, you are not a walking tank that can run through the battlefield taking little to no damage whilst wreaking havoc on your enemies using an array of weapons. In OF you have 4 distinct classes, with different weapon setups, and by playing as the classes you can unlock different weapons to use and more customization options, none of which however are capable of running and gunning through the battelfield due to how easy it is to be killed. Even on normal you can get killed in as few as 2 bullets. Due to this the gameplay is a lot slower paced than other FPS games you may be used too, but it is still very enjoyable. Personally I found it a nice change from the standard FPS games. The story however is rather dissapointing. It's your standard military story where you are in a foreign country trying to restore peace by killing anything that moves, and overall the story is forgettable.Now one of the major downsides to this game is the need to install Games for Windows Live. Youll need to install the GFWL client seperatly from the windows/xbox site before being able to launch the game, and you will need to sign into an Xbox live account in order to play co-op/multiplayer and to be able to save your progress. It's important to note however, that the multiplayer and co-op is still functional despite GFWL not being supported anymore, which is a good thing since the game is a lot more fun to play with friends as the AI squadmates generally are not very useful. The graphics have not aged well and even back in 2011 when the game was launched the graphics weren't that great, and the game isn't optimised that well for PC. With that being said though, the game is still a lot of fun to play, and has a lot of gameplay value, especially for its current low cost. I'd give OF:Red River a solid 7/10 PS: The game plays a little smoother with a xbox controller over keyboard and mouse, but is still playable with them if you don't happen to have a controller. Also GFWL may not be getting updated anymore, but it works fine, so people should stop complaining about the game and giving it bad ratings based on this one thing.

												Despite there being many perfectly valid criticisms thrown its way, I have to say I still like it. For once - it doesn't have regenerating health - instead, you bleed until you patch yourself up (and then use the the infinite medkit you have, but I guess life isn't perfect). The main problem with it is that it took on the name of a franchise reknowned for its focus on vehicle use and squad (i.e. 8-10 people) tactics taking place in a large open environment. People unfamiliar with the Flashpoint name wouldn't care if Codemasters just called it "Red River" and those who are ended up brewing a turn storm around the game. Other flaws include glitchy grapchis and overall shoddy optimization, but not to the gamebreaking level. Character models look nice, with lots of detail on the marine characters, missions take place across large patches of terrain, and although you are confined to a certain area battlefield-style, it rarely becomes an issue. Missions also sport long rides in the back of a humvee, where the only thing you do is listen to the tutorial voice in the form of your platoon's staff sergeant. These rides are tedious, but wrighting is decent and the guy is genuinely hilarious  at times (provided you've ever been in the military or are a fan of Generation Kill), and he reminds me of a sergeant in my old unit.Speaking of Generation Kill - both this game and the previous one (Dragon Rising) rip entire dialogues straight out of the show - I guess they ran out of creativity half-way through writing the story.Most annoying of all - the AI. While friendlies can take a little getting used to, but once you get the hang of commanding them they can be made to function, the enemy AI all graduated from the Tajik special ed class and handed an AK - they either stand in the same spot doing nothing or run towards you. Taking cover is also an overly complicated concept for them. Not only that, but they take damage like a china teacup in a bull arena - you'll be lucky to kill one before he♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥himself on a thornbush and bleeds to death.All in all, the game feels very reminiscent of the Brothers in Arms games, except that actual terrain was used for the levels instead of them looking like a collection of conveniently placed chest-high walls. But I wish they ripped a few more elements off that franchise as well, like the gun accuracy and sway, and maybe the unlobotomized AI while they're at it.

												This review will focus mostly on the negative sides of the game, it doesn't mean that the game is bad, I just talk about the negative  things more.I have no idea why do people compare thisto ARMA or Battlefield. This game is totally different than the first Opflash. People should do  some research before purchase instead of blindly buying games then complain about them. This is not an open world or überrealistic  game. It's an arcade shooter just like COD or MOH.The graphics are not the best but they are totally okay. The optimization is not too  good, eats a lot of resources while the visuals are not too satisfying. There is one effect I really loved though - the sun flare. OMG this  game has the most beautiful sun flare I've ever seen! It's a real eye candy, I wish more games would have it. Overall the places are a  bit bland because you are somewhere in Tajikistan. This game was made for consoles anyway so yeah the maps aren't too interesting.  It has some nice lanscapes and nice sky though.The shooting is really satisfying. It feels good to shoot with the rifles. Yes, only the rifles because there is no use of smg or shotgun.  The reason is simple: there is no close-quarter mission, there are no indoor missions and the enemy is in long range most of the time.  The gadgets are useless too. It takes ages to switch to a grenade, the tripmine has no use at all - the enemy is only approaching from  front most of the time.You have to choose your class, I played it through with the scout class, you can unlock all kinda cool snipers and scopes. But you  can only attach the nightvision scope to a sniper, so you cant put it to M4 etc. The story is... well I couldn't care less about it. I did not understand most parts because of all that soldier talk. I had no idea what was  an APC until I googled it. So maybe you would like the story if you are into military talk and all that stuff. The leader of the squad is an  assshole. He talks waaaay too much and the way he talks is very irritating. He is a wannabe-tough guy, really makes you say the n-word. Your sqad is quite weird. They are not too bright so it's recommended to play in coop with at least one human squadmate. They  are cute though. Many times they are rushing to heal you. But they never heal themsleves. So you may find yourself babysitting them. Giving them orders is useless. The only orders I've used is hold position and follow me. This game is not a tactical one. Doesn't matter  how bad it will look like a tactical game, it's simply not. After all those negative things I've listed it's a very good game I don't care what people say. I  enjoyed every bit of the game. I've played with a coop partner and it was very awesome. The replayability is high, because you have the chance to max all the classes and  unlock cool weapons and perks. I've played it through as a scout, it was really awesome. If you are looking for a good coop game,  look no further. I enjoyed every minute of it (except mr.assshole's rambling). It's different from most of FPS games because this game is  representing the missions in a more realistic way. I recommend it to everyone who is sick of ww2 nazi killing clichés and want to play a cool FPS in modern setting.PS: The menu music is incredible.DEFEND DAT TAYLOR!

												What I've always appreciated about the Operation Flashpoint games is that you really aren't the hero of the game. You're just another cog in the wheel surrounded by other cogs in the wheel of a fully functional fighting team. Red River is the third (and maybe last in the series) and I really enjoyed it. You're a marine fire team leader thrust into a conflict in a fictional desert country on the border of China. You take control of three AI squad members who you can give simple orders to. You can flank, suppress fire, hold positions etc. When given the opportunity you'll have access to mortar fire and airstrikes. The complaints about the AI being pretty dumb are unfortunately pretty spot on. Guys will run in front of you, I've had armor wipe out my team and I was run over by HMMWVs more than once. Graphics are servicable and the maps are large but you're also given checkpoints that tell you where to go so they feel limited in that aspect.  Mission variety...well you're in a fire eam so you're going to take and defend buildings, rush the enemy, destroy AA etc. There's a mission where you're falling back position after position because wave after wave of enemies are coming to get you. It can be frustrating but satisfying when you finish. The gunplay is a bit different since you have to account for bullet drop etc. It gets a bit easier as you go along since there's a level up system which allows you to put points towards gun handling, accuracy etc. There is an absolute ton of voice acting and while there were times it was a bit much I didn't mind it too much. Whoever played the Staff Sergeant was very good and reminded me of some of my leadership when I was in the Army. I also got lucky because I had zero issues with the GFWL setup. Saves worked perfectly and got plenty of achievements.  Overall I recommend OF: RR. OF: Dragon Rising is still the superior game but I've seen where you can get both games for $5. That's a great deal. 7.5/10 from me.

												OpFlash Red River is an odd class of shooter that's both based on a realistic subject, and is quite realistic. It is not superbly realistic like the Arma Series, and it has little RPG elements where you fight to gain XP to level up, and use that to improve your various combat skills like sprint, weapon changing, accuracy, scouting, and so on. However, it is a welcome change from the usual "blistering pace shoot everything" type shooter (such as Call of Duty Modern Warfare series, or the Medal of Honor series). You control Fireteam Bravo, one of the four marines in Tajikistan, where the US had gone in to take out the guerilla forces aiding the Taliban and Al Qaeda. You will have plenty of friendlies in the campaign missions (fireteams Alpha and Charlie) and various support elements (if any). You can play as one of four classes, rifleman, scout/sniper, grenadier, and autogunner/LMG, each with their "skills" and "weapons" and accessories to unlock. There are 10 main campaign missions, and they are quite long, with a lot of sub-objectives and waypoints. When you are done with those, there are "fireteam engagements" (your fireteam against everybody else) you can play. Generally AI handles the other 3 team members, but if you want multiplayer other players can take over those 3 slots. Graphics are quite good, and campaign missions are quite good, if a bit on the difficult side, as even on easy you WILL get killed A LOT and not knowing where you did wrong. All in all, if you crave a "realistic" shooter and can't stand Modern Warfare you may want to give this one a try.

												I definitiely recommend this game. You WILL have to get through GFWL, however. It was a real pain to set up for the first time, mainly becuase I had forgotten my password to my account. It takes a few minutes to get past the humps, but once you are in, there are no issues whatsoever. To preface, you may have a sound issue. I am running on Win 8 using a Toshiba Satellite L-55B. Going into my sound settings in the control panel and disabling the microphone solved the sound issue for me. After almost 40 hours into the game, 1/3 through my third playthrough, I can say there is a slight learning curve. It is unlike some FPS games where you can basically rush in. It is all about tactics, or you will make it harder for yourself. You must utilize fireteam orders, even better if you can manage ordering specific fireteam members during engagements. Especially when you get about halfway through. For those that haven't picked this game up yet and haven't researched it yet, I will leave out spoilers.Biggest con about the game, and I personally wouldn't consider it a deal breaker, is that the AI classes do not gain experience during the campaign. Your very first playthrough is going to be rough, becuase you have not gained access to any good equipement or B-Mods. To sum it up, the only way to gain expereince with a class is to play as that class in the campaign. I did my first playthrough with the default starting class, the Rifleman. My second playthrough was with the Scout (sniper), and I can say I'd recommend doing your first playthrough as the Scout. You will definitely learn how to compesnate for bullet drop much quicker, your main weapon deals max damage (very handy when it comes time to deal with armored enemies), and is semi-automatic for quick, instant death shots regardless of placement. Again, that will come in handy later on in the game, becuase it will get very hairy every mission. The Autorifleman is also a good one to start with (my third and current playthrough) because your weapon will hold 200 rounds, which helps with supression and large groups, without going dry quickly. That will allow you to get through just about any engagement without having to reload constantly. That is really the only con. The repetitive dialogue is getting a little old, but it doesn't bother me. Now for the PROS!This game has very good replay value. Even after my third playthrough I still get excited when accomplishing the mission goals, and it is rewarding. Especially hearing that sound when leveling up. The is why I don't consider my above con to be a deal breaker, because playing through from the start as a different class allows you to gain experience for that class, allowing any AI playing as the class you had used from the previous playthrough to utlilize the unlocked gear and B-Mods which makes it worth it, as your fireteam will be kicking some serious butt with the increased accuracy and damage endurance. Since my Rifleman and Scout are max level, more often than not they will pick off kills before I even have a chance, whereas compared to my first playthrough I was basically doing all the work. I could keep going, but I'm heading back to the game now. It's worth the $9.99 and effort to get through first time setup with GFWL. And don't worry, your game will save.Good hunting!

You'll be fighting against terrorist hostiles in the desert, while also dealing with the People's Liberation Army of China.+ Story wise I would say the game is decent, but it doesn't feature anything out of the ordinary or ground-breaking. It's a pretty standard tale of U.S forces securing key objectives like dams and defending Fall Out Bases.+ As with the first title, Operation Flashpoint: Red River closely resembles a military simulator, so it's great for gamers who want to play tactically.+ Graphics are passable, not top notch in any respect, but reasonable.Negatives:- The guns just don't seem as fluid as the original game. I can't quite put my finger on it, but something is odd. The weapons just appear to be less exciting and more generic. The feeling you have when firing isn't the same as in Operation Flashpoint: Dragon Rising. I'm not complaining about the realism of the weapons, they just have no charm. In Operation Flashpoint: Dragon Rising, they were both very fun to use and realistic.- Squad commands are once again a pain to initiate. Really poorly thought-out system that simply doesn't work as intended in the middle of shooting at enemies. Too time consuming and difficult to do. I finished the game purely by solo killing, with my teammates behind me providing default covering fire.- The game can start out slow, most of the missions aren't too engaging in terms of gameplay. While the new desert atmosphere is nice, it can also be a bit bland at the same time.- Game is short at 20 hours, although this isn't the worst length for a First Person Shooter I've come across.- Voice acting is kinda strange to be honest..just a little.Overall Score: 6/10Operation Flashpoint: Red River isn't a bad game. It's just not as good as the Operation Flashpoint: Dragon Rising. It's shorter, the guns aren't as enjoyable, the environment is fresh and new, but it doesn't have the X factor that Operation Flashpoint: Dragon Rising retained. In the end, it's a game still worth purchasing, but definitely on sale.

												It's an even bigger departure from it's simulation namesake, however Red River still holds it's own as a decent squad based tactical shooter. The player retains the role of a USMC Fireteam Leader as they guide their fellow Marines and command them to complete the varied mission objectives thrown at them during the campaign.Pros:- Game offers a decent amount of tactical flexibaility with it's command system.- Players will work alongside seperate AI Fireteams as part of a larger Squad, making the player feel a part of a larger war effort.- Friendly AI now have their own personality, the voice acting is much less robotic than previous games and the natural banter increases immersion.-The new voice acting comes with a script full of excessive swearing and less than politically correct comments. It may be confronting at first but I feel it is a realistic and accurate representation of military banter, adds to the immersion and makes the player feel like they're part of a human squad of soldiers.- Players can now unlock new weapons and equipment, and customise their loadout prior to each mission.Cons:- Missions are more linear than the previous game.- AI still occasionaly glitch or bug out.- Lack of Mission Editor (a staple of the series) hinders replayabilty.- The new voice acting comes with a script full of excessive swearing and less than politically correct comments. I personally have no problem with this as I found it to be an accurate depiction of military banter, but some players may find this uncomfortable.I can reccomend this game for players looking for a more thought based shooter. While it's not as in depth as it's predecessors or rival series (ArmA) it still requires a little bit of patience and strategy to survive the firefights in this campaign.

												It's an even bigger departure from it's simulation namesake, however Red River still holds it's own as a decent squad based tactical shooter. The player retains the role of a USMC Fireteam Leader as they guide their fellow Marines and command them to complete the varied mission objectives thrown at them during the campaign.Pros:- Game offers a decent amount of tactical flexibaility with it's command system.- Players will work alongside seperate AI Fireteams as part of a larger Squad, making the player feel a part of a larger war effort.- Friendly AI now have their own personality, the voice acting is much less robotic than previous games and the natural banter increases immersion.-The new voice acting comes with a script full of excessive swearing and less than politically correct comments. It may be confronting at first but I feel it is a realistic and accurate representation of military banter, adds to the immersion and makes the player feel like they're part of a human squad of soldiers.- Players can now unlock new weapons and equipment, and customise their loadout prior to each mission.Cons:- Missions are more linear than the previous game.- AI still occasionaly glitch or bug out.- Lack of Mission Editor (a staple of the series) hinders replayabilty.- The new voice acting comes with a script full of excessive swearing and less than politically correct comments. I personally have no problem with this as I found it to be an accurate depiction of military banter, but some players may find this uncomfortable.I can reccomend this game for players looking for a more thought based shooter. While it's not as in depth as it's predecessors or rival series (ArmA) it still requires a little bit of patience and strategy to survive the firefights in this campaign.

												나름 괜찮은 FPS 게임이다. 중국을 대상으로 벌이는 전투는 신박했으며, 중국의 인해전술의 무서움을 제대로 느껴볼 수 있다. 무섭다기 보단 심히 피로해진다. 본디 아르마와 아버지는 같으나, 아르마가 이 작품의 뿌리에서 분리(퇴사)되어 만들어진 정신적인 후속작인 반면, 이 작품은 초기의 모습을 거의 버리고 '라이트'함을 계속 꾸준히 증가시킨 계통으로 보면 된다. 사뭇 진지한 밀리터리 물이고, 여타 다른 쉬운 FPS에 비해서 난이도가 좀 있는 편이지만 다른 빡센 작품들에 비하면 아주 쉬운편. (레드 오케스트라, 아르마를 해보라...어렵다) 게임 자첸 평이하게 만들었고, 그래픽도 준수하나.. 차량 이동 파트에서 너무 시간을 잡아먹기 때문에 전투를 하면서 전혀 긴장감을 느낄 수 없다. 브라보 분대에 소속된 주인공 중 한 명을 맡아서 하는데, 이 때 자신의 역할을 선택할 수 있다. 소총수, 스나이퍼, 공병 등의 역할을 선택하고 그 역할로 진행하면 해당 역할에 대한 레벨이 오르는데 이 때 퍽이나 무기 선택 폭이 다양해지는 방식이다. 달리기, 정확도 등의 스킬도 따로 키워 줄 수 있다. 혼자서 하게되면 AI 3개를 통솔하는 브라보 팀의 분대장이 되며, 코옵을 하게될 경우 1P가 분대장을 맡게된다. AI들이 생각보다 멍청해서 좀 고생이 심한데, 분대장(또는 플레이어)이 내리는 통솔 명령을 시기적절하게만 잘 써주면 치료도 해주러 오며, 공격, 대기 등 세밀한 명령이 가능하다. 근데 신경을 전혀 안쓰면 애들이 안 움직이거나 너무 멍청해져서 고생이 심해진다. 하다보면 애들이 이미 죽어있을 정도. 총 10개의 미션을 진행하는데 처음엔 플탐이 적어도 후반을 갈 수록 미션 하나 당 플탐이 많이 소요되는 것도 특징. 이유는 맵이 넓고(아름답다), 서브 미션이 생각보다 다양하기 때문이다. 전쟁이라기 보다는 특수 부대 임무를 띄는 느낌이 강한 편. 혼자서 하면 재미를 아주 못느낄 가능성이 농후하지만, 친구와 같이 한다면 '코옵'이라는 마법의 작용으로 생각보다 재밌어진다. GFWL 제거 예정에 없는 게임이지만, 2014년 7월 1일에 종료한다던 GFWL 서비스가 연장됨에 따라 가지고 있다면 지인들과 분대를 짜서 플레이해보는 것도 좋을 것이다.

												Codemasters started a new side studio called "Codemasters Guildford" to handle making these two Operation Flashpoint games, and they sucked so bad that Codemasters shut down the studio and went back to focusing on their racing games.Got this and a few other games at humblebundle for $1 to try out. This was such a bad experience that I am not even going to bother with the other game, Operation Flashpoint: Dragon Rising. Out of the hundreds of games I've played since becoming a PC gamer back in 1997, there are only a few games that I have ever quit playing and uninstalled within 30 minutes, and this is one of them.First, I can without even the slightest hesitation say that this game has some of the worst voice acting of all time. It is cringe-inducingly bad. It is so bad it made me physically ill and I pooped all over.This games problems start right away. It is immediately obvious how bad this game is when you start by doing nearly five minutes of riding with your squad in a humvee while a guy talks the ENTIRE time, enough to fill five pages of a book. He just very monotonely drones on and not one single word he says is of any importance whatsoever, just incredibly, mind jarringly annoying. After what feels like twenty minutes rather than five, you get out in a little area and get to kill two guys, then five more minutes of driving and him talking nonsense until your ears bleed. You get out in another small area & kill a few more guys, then five more minutes of driving and you get to assault a small town. In the middle of the assault is when I had enough and alt+f4 out and uninstalled. First off, that insane amount of riding in a humvee is unneeded. The guy rambling the entire time talking more than anything I've ever heard, even more than in a Mass Effect game, is uncalled for.Also, the gameplay is like something out of a paper cut-out book. My rifle barely moved when I fired it, the sound was bad, sounded like a kids toy gun, when your bullets hit an enemy it feels laughably uneventful and generic, the sight aim sensitivity blows, and the squad command menu is without a doubt completely unnecessary and is just a burden. The basic things you can tell your squad to do are things that are automatically done by the ai in any good game because they are basic actions that should be automatically programmed into the game for the AI, but here are left out to make you feel like you are giving them strategic commands, lol. It's like they said "the game's AI isn't finished yet so we gave you commands to do it yourself".Where Battlefield 3 would be a 8 or 9/10, this game is like a bottom of the barrel, stripped down, generic, awkward copy of BF3 and would at best be a 3/10. BF3 is a guy with a 20,000 dollar suit on and this game is a homeless guy laying in his own p1ss in the gutter begging for booze money. Codemasters' Dirt games, more specifically Dirt 3, is one of the most well made racing games I've ever played. I do not know what they were thinking trying to make this garbage horse crap of a war fps game, but they would have been better off not doing so. Especially since they took a hit on these games financially and shut down the side company they started in order to make them.To this game's credit, as god awful as it is, its engine is still astoundingly better than ARMA 2's, lol. But then again, Asteroids for Atari has a better game engine than ARMA 2 so that's not saying much.Anyone who actually likes and spends any time on these two Op Flash games is probably a recluse with no sense of human interaction and a horrible taste in games and should stop wasting time and kill themselves quickly.A diaper filled with sh-t/10

												OFP: Red River is a very average shooter, and nothing more. When it comes to realism, it's somewhere between Call of Duty and ARMA with one-hit kills, large maps and bullet drops etc. If you excpect something like the first OFP games, you will be disappointed and I recommend trying ARMA II and ARMA III instead.The single player campaign is very dull and annoying, and this is mostly because of the dumbass AI. You basically have to fulfill the role of fireteam leader, combat medic, anti-tank and anti-air soldier and also the sniper. Your fireteam is only good for suppressing enemies and they occasionally succeed in busting a cap in the a*s of a random chinaman, but usually they just annoy the hell out of me by getting shot and not fixing me up when I get wounded. The enemy AI is as stupid as the one of your teammates, and most of the firefights feel like being at a shooting gallery popping seemingly endless amounts of infantry from a distance.The story is pretty basic "hoorah murica get sum" action with the U.S Marines saving the world, first from the evil imaginary taleban-Tajikistans, and then from the Chinese Army.The best moments of the game are when you have room to improvise and can use the vast landscape to flank the enemy, but unfortunately these moments are too few. Most missions are just shooting couple of enemies, sitting on the back of a HUMMVEE and repeating it all over again. The co-op feature pretty much saves the games, since if you have a couple of friends you don't have to deal with the dumbass AI all the time. There is also a leveling system with some customization available and you can unlock new gear and weapons for four different classes, which is nice and rewarding.If you enjoy FPS-games and want something more slower-paced than Call of Duty and Battlefield, try this one out. It was featured in one of the Humble Bundles a while back. It's still very buggy, although it has been out for years and it also forces you to use GFWL, which sucks.

												Don't be turned away by the "Mixed" stigma and that scary, danger-orange coloring to the same type-written word. This game has real meat to it, real substance that gives the game lasting value.  I've owned this game and played it off and on since its release in 2011: Operation Flashpoint Red River is worth your ten bucks ten times over.Red River is about as realistic as you choose, and your "Normal" difficulty rating still hammers home that this is a tactical, infantry-based military sim. Some corners are glossed over in a comesmetic way (e.g. Fireteam members completely restored at save checkpoints in the single-player campaign) which some find unappealing and what I'll bet you is the number one focus of complaints.The multiplayer options of the game are quite awesome if you pause to think about truly seamless the integration of co-op into Fireteam Missions and even the Campaign. Player Progress and Class Setup (rewards for Achievements etc.) are just whipped cream on a trifecta wedding cake.

												Honestly, this game could have been pretty good. However, it turned out to be a really cheesy let-down, which really upset me after recently playing the previous title (Operation flashpoint - Dragon Rising) which was released two years before this game. The graphics are garbage compared to the previous game. The voice acting is cheesy, stupid, and annoying. Overall, this game feels like a bad version of an early Call of Duty game. I think the developers screwed up by moving away from the realism and simulation feeling which was present in Dragon Rising. Rather than feeling like your part of the action, you instead feel like you’re part of an interactive movie with really bad directions.This game is ok to play, but I can't really stand more than a mission or two per day, whereas I can play most other shooter campaigns for hours on end.
